title: Effects of cap on mRNA stability

content.question: Read each question carefully. Write your response in the space provided for each part of each question. Answers must be written out in paragraph form. Outlines, bulleted lists, or diagrams alone are not acceptable and will not be scored. Researchers are studying the use of <math alttext="R N A " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>RNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> vaccines to protect individuals against certain diseases. To develop the vaccines, particular cells are first removed from an individual. Then <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> coding for specific proteins from a pathogen are introduced into the cells. The altered cells are injected back into the individual, where the cells make the proteins encoded by the introduced <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The individual then produces an immune response to the proteins that will help to protect the individual from developing a disease if exposed to the pathogen in the future. When introduced into cells, the <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> used for vaccines must be stable so that they are not degraded before the encoded proteins are produced. Researchers developed several modified caps that they hypothesized might make the introduced <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> more stable than <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with the normal <math alttext="G T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cap. To test the effect of the modified caps, the researchers produced <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that differed only in their cap structure (no cap, the normal cap, or modified caps <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, or <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). They introduced the same amount of each <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to different groups of cells and measured the amount of time required for half of the <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to degrade (<math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> half-life) and the total amount of protein translated from the <math alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (Table 1). TABLE 1. EFFECT OF <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> CAP STRUCTURE ON <math alttext="m R N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> HALF-LIFE AND PROTEIN TRANSLATED FROM THE INTRODUCED <math alttext="m R N A" (relative to amount in normal cap) No cap <math alttext="1.41 plus or minus 0.02" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.41</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>0.02</mn></math> <math alttext="0.011 plus or minus 0.000" alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from degradation.

alttext="m R N As " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from degradation.

(b) Based on the data for the <math alttext="m R N As " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> with modified caps, describe the relationship between the <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> half-life and the total amount of protein produced.

(c) After examining the data on <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> half-lives and the amount of protein produced, the researchers hypothesized that each <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule with modified cap <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was translated more frequently than was each <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule with the normal <math alttext="G T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cap. Evaluate their hypothesis by comparing the data in Table 1.

(d) Introduction of <math alttext="m R N As" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNAs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into cells allows the cells to produce foreign proteins that they might not normally produce. Explain why the production of a foreign protein may be more likely from the introduction of <math alttext="m R N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>mRNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> than <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into cells.

skill.text: 4.B: Describe data from a table or graph, including: i. identifying specific data points ii. describing trends and patterns in the data iii. describing relationships between variables
